speaker: Kirsten Gillibrand
vclaim: "A black woman in New York City is 12 times more likely to die in childbirth than a white woman."
date: stated on February 7, 2019 in a tweet:
title: Gillibrand raises the issue of racial disparity in maternal health care
text: Following the election campaign, Ms. Christine Gilbert repeatedly spoke about her experiences as a mother and how this role guides her political positions. She has been talking about maternal health for some time and has raised the issue of racial disparities in the health-care system. In a recent tweet, the presidential candidate wrote: "A black woman in New York City is 12 times more likely to die in childbirth than a white woman. This is not an accident - it is a failure of politics and justice, and it is a failure that we cannot accept. We have a moral responsibility to correct it." Is Gilbrand's allegation true? We have referred Whitney Mitchell Brennan, a spokesman for Gilbert, to a report by Merck Pharmaceuticals, as well as several news stories and editorial articles repeating these statistics. A report entitled "Mother's March" on maternal mortality and morbidity in New York indicates that the United States is one of "a very few developed countries where maternal or neonatal mortality is increasing." A report from the New York City Ministry of Health and Mental Health, Office of Maternal, Infant and Reproductive Health, is the source of the statistics concerned. The Office used "enhanced surveillance" to collect data on pregnancy-related deaths in New York City between 2006 and 2010. This means that the Office used "multiple data sources to identify and review deaths occurring during pregnancy or within one year of the end of pregnancy." This is the latest available data, according to Daniel de Souza, the spokesperson for the Section. From 2006 to 2010, the pregnancy-related mortality rate for black and non-Spanish women was 12 times higher than for white and non-Spanish women, according to the report. "This represents an expansion of the gap in pregnancy-related deaths from 2001 to 2005, when the rate of pregnancy-related deaths among non-Spanish black women was seven times higher," by researchers. The gap has widened considerably owing to the 45 per cent drop in the pregnancy-related mortality rate among white and non-Spanish women. Check the facts (Kirk Cox) was mentioned on January 13, 2021 in a speech. Virginia ranked lowest third of the states in the management of the COVID-19 vaccine. • On 20 January 2021, from 2006 to 2010 in New York City, there were 56.3 deaths among non-Spanish black pregnant women per 100,000 live births. During the same period, there were 4.7 deaths among white and non-Spanish pregnant women per 100,000 live births. The rates for both categories fell from 2001-2005, when 61.7 black women died and 8.6 white women died per 100,000 live births. From 2006 to 2010, Asian/Pacific women were four times more likely than women of Spanish origin to die than a white woman due to pregnancy, as researchers found. The report defines pregnancy-related deaths as "death of a woman during pregnancy or within one year of the termination of pregnancy from any reason connected with or aggravated by pregnancy or her administration. In such cases, pregnancy and death are causally linked." Although Gilbrand said "childbirth" in this tweet, the speaker sent us examples of the senator using "pregnancy and childbirth" or "controversies related to pregnancy" to describe the statistics involved, or related issues. These examples included further tweeting and a newsletter. The reasons for such large health disparities between black and white mothers are "unestablished" researchers' books. However, pregnancy-related deaths are associated with obesity, basic chronic diseases and poverty, which affect the city ' s black population at higher rates. Researchers have also written that "the chronic stress of racism and social inequality is also likely to contribute to ethnic differences in health." Government and health officials in New York City are trying to address this issue. Our ruling, Gillibrand, said that in New York City, black women are 12 times more likely to die in childbirth than white women. Analysis of data from the New York City Department of Health and Mental Health shows that black women are 12 times more likely to die from pregnancy-related causes than white women during pregnancy or within one year of the end of pregnancy. Because researchers use a broader time frame to analyse pregnancy-related deaths than simply "childbirth," the characterization of Gilbrand needs more context. We appreciate that Gilbrand's statement is mostly true.
